awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Problems of Geophysical Fluid Mechanics:  Uncertainties, Modeling, Theory, and Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project addresses problems of great significance in ocean and atmosphere sciences, related to weather or climate predictions.  The studies have also potential applications in other areas of sciences but this project only addresses the geophysical problems.  The two classes of problems considered are the study of boundary conditions for predictions made in a limited domain, and the study of moist convection, which is related to the understanding of the behavior of clouds.  It is generally considered that our limited understanding of the physics of clouds is a major cause of uncertainty in current weather and climate predictions.  Developing methods that improve weather predictions and climate modeling is an objective of important human, societal, and economical interest.  The training of graduate students and postdoctoral students at the interface of mathematics, geophysical and industrial fluid mechanics, and scientific computing is another broader impact of the project. 

A major problem in developing computational models of geophysical flows, when the flows extend over a large area but the region of particular interest is smaller, is to develop suitable boundary conditions for limited-area models when the physics does not provide natural boundary conditions.  This old problem, already mentioned by von Neumann and Charney, is expected to become very significant.  Indeed, when new computers will allow the use of fine spatial resolutions, it is predicted that inappropriate boundary conditions will introduce spurious modes.  The problem arises also in other contemporary developments like the use of multilevel numerical methods or modeling.  The investigator has obtained a number of relevant results for linear and nonlinear two-dimensional equations.  Here he aims to continue building a sound mathematical theory for the inviscid primitive equations and other related equations.   Concerning the outstanding problem of moist convection, precipitation and clouds, the the problems to be addressed relate to the theory, computations, and modeling.  On the theoretical side, the tools of convex analysis and variational inequalities are used to address questions of existence and uniqueness of solutions for the equations of the humid atmosphere with saturation, which are nonlinear discontinuous partial differential equations (PDEs) not directly connected to any existing PDE theory.  On the modeling side, using again tools of convex analysis, he models the equations of the humid atmosphere corresponding to water clouds below freezing levels by considering a more refined description of the micro physics at saturation, which would introduce additional state parameters.  On the computational side, he studies numerically the superparameterization of the very complex convection phenomena occurring near the equator in the presence of topography, using finite volumes and multilevel methods.   The importance of these phenomena, which involve tropical rains and affect the climate far into the mid-latitude regions, is well known.   Finally, certain questions of probability are addressed in connection with the modeling of the many uncertainties occurring in the phenomena described above.   Graduate students and postdoctoral students are engaged in the work of the project.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

When performing numerical simulations for weather or oceanic predictions, a spatial domain of interest is chosen for computational convenience or physical relevance. Beside the equations to be solved in the domain involving such data as temperature, speed of wind (or of water in the oceans), one has to consider some equations at the boundary of the computational domain, called the boundary conditions. A problem which was already identified by von Neumann and Charney in the 1950's is that there are no physical law giving the boundary conditions for a nonphysical domain. It is believed that future calculations involving high performance computers will demand a more refined approach to the problem than the empirical rules currently used. Arguing that boundary conditions that make the problems well-posed in the mathematical sense are good candidates for the boundary conditions, we have developed various boundary conditions for various essential equations of geophysical fluid dynamics. During the period of this grant we have determined the appropriate boundary conditions for the inviscid shallow water equations, each mode of the so-called Primitive Equations corresponding to a sort of shallow water equation. Lately, we have tackled the analysis of the inviscid Primitive Equations by letting the viscosity go to zero in the viscous primitive equations, with the intent to thus determine the appropriate boundary conditions for the inviscid Primitive Equations. We believe that the boundary conditions of the limit problem are the appropriate boundary conditions for the inviscid primitive equations. We have completed this project by studying the highly challenging case of the subcritical modes.

Beside the theoretical approach, we performed numerical simulations which confirmed the relevance of the boundary conditions that we propose. For the classical example of the Equatorial Rossby Soliton (http://marine.rutgers.edu/po/tests/rossby/index.html), our simulations show that the soliton freely leaves the domain on its west boundary, whereas the proposed boundary condition, and all common boundary conditions induce unrealistic reflections of the soliton at the western and then eastern boundaries.

Another major problem in geophysical sciences that we have tackled is the study of the humid atmosphere with saturation. A phenomenon as common as the clouds is nevertheless far to be understood from the physical point of view and the specialists believe that the clouds are the greatest source of uncertainty regarding the current numerical simulations for the weather. The clouds play a major role in the energetic balance of the Earth. Through a variety of physical processes, the clouds affect the small vertical convective structures which transport heat and humidity, and the large global structures which carry the heat from the tropics to the great latitudes, and the other structures such as the monsoon and El Nino.

The clouds are a multi-scale phenomenon and about 3 scales in times and 14 scales in space are necessary for a good description of the clouds, which is far beyond our current computing power.

For a better description of clouds in the future, it will be necessary to use the full equations describing the evolution of each of its components (air, water vapor, liquid water, ice, pollutants, etc.). Because of the changes of phase, these equations are discontinuous nonlinear partial differential equations, a subject highly challenging for mathematicians, modelers and computer scientists.

During the time of this award we have developed the study of the equations of the humid atmosphere with saturation, which had never been made before. As we said these equations are non-linear, and non-continuous. We have introduced a new mathematical formulation of the equations of the humid atmosphere with saturation using the concept of quasi-variational inequalities. Based on this formulation we have proved the existence, uniqueness and regularity of solutions for several models. We also described numerical algorithms for solving these equations.

Finally, we extensively worked on Stochastic Partial Differential Equations (SPDEs). The initial motivation to study SPDEs comes from the difficulties connected with their numerical analysis. Very little is known about this issue; this question was pointed out to me a few years ago by a specialist of geophysical fluid dynamics. In this direction, as an upfront work we have studied stochastic partial differential equations driven by a Levy noise which have been recently proposed to model bursts of wind. We have completed two review papers and several original articles regarding SPDEs driven by a Levy noise.

Concerning the broader impact of this research, I should mention that our graduate students have been very successful at finding jobs. In particular, in industry, there seems to be a new interest in mathematicians qualified in these areas of modeling, partial differential equations, numerical methods and stochastic equations. These jobs are highly technical and different from the standard financial math jobs.

This PI thanks NSF for its support for this award and for many years of support of his research.
